title: Row breaks out after official-looking sign over feeding bread to ducks
text:
It was once a gentle pleasure enjoyed by children and adults alike.

But the issue of feeding bread to ducks has provoked an angry dispute over whether it puts the birds at risk.

It was sparked when an official-looking sign appeared at a pond in Derbyshire saying ducks were ‘dying of starvation’ after warnings in recent years that bread was bad for their health.

The official-looking sign appeared at a pond at Pavilion Gardens in Buxton, Derbyshire, saying ducks were ‘dying of starvation’

It urged visitors to feed them, saying the warnings were wrong and that while bread is ‘not the healthiest for us… nothing in our bellies will kill us’.

A photo of the sign was posted online and shared 17,000 times, fuelling a debate that left commentators saying they were confused over contradictory advice.

Louisa Taylor, who shared a photo of the sign from the Pavilion Gardens in Buxton, said she felt forced to delete it after an angry backlash.

‘I have two young children so I don’t need the stress of it,’ she added. ‘I honestly thought I was doing a good deed.’

The woman who originally took the photo did not want to be named because she too feared a backlash.

She told the BBC: ‘There had been signs up the year before saying you can’t feed bread to the ducks any more, but then this sign was saying the ducks were dying and starving.

The issue of feeding bread to ducks has provoked an angry dispute over whether it puts the birds at risk (file image)

‘I’ve no idea who’s put it up. It was only up for a few days. It’s confusing.’ Experts are divided on the issue. The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds said it was fine to feed small amounts of bread to ducks but they should also get sweetcorn, porridge oats, peas and bird seed.

Tony Whitehead, of the charity, said: ‘Just like us, birds need a varied diet to stay healthy.’

The Canal and River Trust has previously campaigned against feeding bread to ducks, saying: ‘Uneaten soggy bread can cause a build-up of bad nutrients which can lead to greater algal growth, spread disease and encourage pests such as rats.’

But Swan Support, which rescues swans, ducks and geese, said some were starving because people had stopped feeding them bread. It blamed a campaign called Ban the Bread by a company selling bird food.

The charity’s Wendy Hermon said: ‘Bread has been fed to swans, ducks and geese for hundreds of years. It’s absolutely fine to feed bread.’

The Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust said feeding birds a small amount of bread was safe as part of a varied diet that also included vegetables and grain.
description: A photo of a sign near at pond in Pavilion Gardens in Buxton, Derbyshire has fuelled a debate over whether or not it is okay to feed bread to ducks. The sign said the warnings about bread were wrong.
authors: Claire Duffin For The Daily Mail
